# Scale: Major in E (Mode: Locrian)

## Brief Presentation
The E Major scale, when played in the Locrian mode, is a scale that starts on the seventh degree of the major scale. In this case, starting on the seventh degree of the D Major scale results in the E Locrian scale. It is a lesser-used mode due to its dissonant-sounding nature and its unique interval structure.

## Notes and Intervals
The E Locrian scale consists of the following notes and intervals:
- E (Root)
- F (Minor 2nd)
- G (Minor 3rd)
- A (Perfect 4th)
- Bb (Diminished 5th)
- C (Minor 6th)
- D (Minor 7th)
- E (Octave)

The interval structure of this scale is: 
- Whole, Half, Whole, Whole, Half, Whole, Whole

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The E Locrian scale is not commonly used in mainstream music genres due to its dissonant and unresolved sound. It can lend a darker, suspenseful, and mysterious quality to music when utilized effectively. It is often found in more experimental or avant-garde genres such as jazz fusion, progressive rock, and certain types of metal.

## Songs
Here are three songs that make use of the E Locrian scale:
1. "The Dance of Eternity" by Dream Theater
2. "Fracture" by King Crimson
3. "Black Sabbath" by Black Sabbath

These songs showcase the unique and distinctive sound that the Locrian mode in E can bring to music compositions.
